column6:
This clause requires for us to confirm about the participation of "Subject Individuals"  These are defined as a current FAA employee's father, mother, son, daughter, brother, sister, uncle, aunt, first cousin, nephew, niece, husband, wife, father-in-law, mother-in-law, son-in-law, daughter-in-law, brother-in-law, sister-in-law, stepfather, stepmother, stepson, stepdaughter, stepbrother, stepsister, half brother, half sister, spouse of an in-law, or a member of his/her household.  This would be extremely cumbersome to track. 

Suggest removal. Virginia Tech will not be performing "support services" and will, instead, be executing research.  This does not apply.

column2: Notice and Assistance Regarding Patent and Copyright Infringement

column5:
Must insert the clause in SIRs and contracts that may result in the delivery of commercial items, unless both complete performance and delivery are outside the United States. This clause may also be used when the contracting officer determines, after consultation with legal counsel, that omission of the clause would be consistent with commercial practice.

The contracting officer must not include in any SIR or contract any clause whereby the Government agrees to indemnify a contractor for patent infringement.
column6:
As a state agency, Virginia Tech is prohibited from indemnifying other parties without approval from the Governor [see Va Code section 2.2-1837]. The basis for an agency's inability to agree to an indemnification agreement or the payment of attorney's fees and court costs is rooted in Virginia Constitution Article X, Section 9, which prohibits any debt other than (1) debts to meet emergencies and redeem previous debt obligations, (2) general obligation debt for capital projects and sinking fund, or (3) debts for certain revenue-producing capital projects. None of these exceptions permit the state to incur a debt such as that contemplated by an indemnification agreement or the payment of attorney's fees and court costs.

Also, Virginia Tech is not providing commercial items.  Therefore, this clause should not apply.

column5: Must insert the clause in fixed-price SIRs and contracts when royalties may be paid under the contract. This really is not not applicable to Virginia Tech.  GIDEP provides the following information on supplies (and Virginia Tech is not providing supplies):

(1) A means for reporting Suspected Unapproved Parts (SUPS)
(2) Source for Diminishing Manufacturing Sources and Material Shortages (DMSMS) information.
(3) Source for Parts Obsolescence Resolutions.
(4) Source for Non-Conforming Products.
(5) Source for Failure Experience Data.
(6) Source for Safe Alerts.
(7) Source for Urgent Data Request (UDR) A service and process for finding information not available in the GIDEP data base.

column2: Alternate I, Security Requirements - Classified Contracts
column5:
Must be used in SIRs and contracts for research and development with an educational institution when the contract requires access to information that is classified as "Confidential", or "Secret", or "Top Secret".

NOTIFY OESRC
column6: We request for this clause to be included with its Alternate I as this modifies the clause to add paragraphs (e), (f), and (g).  These additional paragraphs are very important because, if the security requirements change, we are required to exert every reasonable effort compatible with our established policies to continue to perform the work.  If we are unable to continue work after exerting reasonable efforts, we are required to notify the Contracting Officer.  Then, the Contracting Officer works to find a mutually satisfactory method to allow for work to continue.  If that is not possible, we are allowed to ask for a partial or full termination of the award.  This is a good thing, as it protects the University from being bound to meet security requirements that we are unable to comply with.
